thread.title: No selfie sacrifice for our new PM Malcolm Turnbull
thread.title_full: No selfie sacrifice for our new PM Malcolm Turnbull

author: CBD
title: No selfie sacrifice for our new PM Malcolm Turnbull
text:
Illustration: John Shakespeare
Our new PM Malcolm Turnbull is having to deal with a fair bit of baggage from the very conservative reign of his predecessor, Tony Abbott .
But he has chosen to keep one of Abbott's less contentious foibles by hiring his own official prime ministerial photographer.
He has not kept Abbott's man, former Daily Telegraph photographer, Brad Hunter .
In what may be a nod to his more centrist approach, Turnbull has hired former Fairfax man, Sahlan Hayes .
Advertisement And it appears that the role is not designed to compete with media groups, like Fairfax and News Corp, for shots of the PM.
In keeping with his social media friendly approach to the top office, Hayes' brief is to capture the behind the scenes activity of our PM – and provide ample fodder for Turnbull's 465,000 Twitter followers.
CBD can't wait to see what images comeback from next month's meet and greet between the new PM and attendees at National Mining Day (NMD), which is being held at Parliament House November 23.
Turnbull is expected to show up and play nice with the Peter Charlton -founded mining champion, and press the flesh with the likes of Rio Tinto's Sam Walsh .
This should make it interesting if the NMD's patron – Tony Abbott fan, Gina Rinehart – shows up to the event.
Look out for the Hayes 'selfie' of our PM, Rinehart and her $200 million benefactor, Walsh.
Apprentice wages Not everyone has been a big fan of Mark Bouris 's Celebrity Apprentice – despite the millions thrown at the reality TV series by his listed wealth outfit, Yellow Brick Road.
It "continues to bring you the adventures of people who are barely celebrities competing to not actually be anyone's apprentice" was a rather unkind verdict from CBD colleagues at the Sydney Morning Herald and The Age .
Then again, what else were we expecting when the celebrity list includes Geoffrey Edelsten and Gabi Greko .
And viewing numbers seen by CBD suggest that one celebrity apprentice, Blake Garvey , may have attracted more viewers as the star of The Bachelor .
But CBD can assure YBR investors of one thing, the company said their executive chairman Bouris is not being paid a cent to appear on the show.
That is worth keeping in mind as investors gear up for next month's shareholder meeting.
Rock the boat ANZ's former rock star boss, John McFarlane , has continued to channel his inner Iggy Pop despite landing the plum role of Barclays' chairman.
There he was at the British Bankers' Association annual conference telling his colleagues that investment bankers shouldn't get ridiculous bonuses.
Apparently it only encourages bad behaviour, and a duty of care that that evaporates the moment the bonus hits the Swiss bank account.
"If I had my own way, and this can never happen, I would reward people at the end, once you know the results sometimes three or five years down the road," he said.
"At least you are then rewarding them for what you know in terms of the value they have created."
Alas, the damn yankee banks set the compensation bar, so Barclays has no choice but to play the same game as everyone else.
"I don't think we can pay people less than the market price, and that implies that if you want to control costs, you want to operate with as few people as possible," he said.
So the bottomline is, Barclays is continuing to pay its investment bankers ridiculous bonuses that encourage bad behaviour and short term thinking. But it's good to know McFarlane's intentions are pure.
Cop out Colourful copper hopeful, CuDeco, reports that its accounts for the year ending June 30 continue to be delayed while it crunches the numbers on the valuation of its Cloncurry, Queensland copper deposit.
It must be hard to translate the the metallurgical properties of Cloncurry's native copper – described by CuDeco founder, Wayne McCrae , as "just like dried dog shit" – into a respectable balance sheet line item.
The good news is that CuDeco expects to finish the exercise by the end of this week, and report any impairments of its much prized asset.
